TIIR iroUSRMAN AND FAIR WORLD ATTENTION OHIO HARNESS HORSEMEN AS OF MARCH 30 PURSE CONTRACTS HAVE NOT BEEN SIGNED WITH NORTHFIELD PARK RACEWAY PARK SCIOTO DOWNS Painesville Meeting Toledo-Maumee Scioto Meeting Qrandview Meeting MARA Meeting Northfield Meeting Raceway Meeting The Ohio Harness Horsemen's Association, Inc. has signed three year contracts with Lebanon Trotting Club, Inc. and Hamilton Racing Association, Inc., covering the 1974 thru 1976 meetings at Lebanon Raceway. All other Ohio tracks have refused to agree on similar conditions although they were offered such contracts. Although negotiations are continuing, horsemen should know that contracts are not signed and the Ohio Harness Horsemen's Association members should govern themselves accordingly. Because contracts have not been signed, some tracks are refusing to allow horsemen early training privileges at their track. This policy is solely a decision of management. in view of the increased costs of feed, equipment, training, shipping, etc., we feel that horsemen must carefully consider the effects of any contracts covering racing at the unsigned Ohio tracks. The Ohio Harness Horsemen's Association, Inc. will not agree to any contract that is not fair and reasonable. Your support is necessary at this critical time in harness racing in Ohio. The only way we can fail you is if you fail us. OHIO HARNESS HORSEMEN'S ASSOCIATION, INC. 28^2 North Franklin Street RIchwood, Ohio 43344 APRIL 3, 1074 CLM. MIdgett, Elizabeth Ciiy, North Carolina YIELD, bc, Speedster-Rosy Picture Eighty Trotters Eligible To THU HORSEMAN AND FAIR WORLD $100,000 Kentucky Futurity Lexington,Ky.—Eighty S-year-old Irollers liave made the final sustaining payment for the 1974 Kentucky Futurity — 76 colts and four fillies. The field which will contest tlie first $100,000 Kentucky Futurity at the Red Mile in October includes 14 of last season's 2:05 two-year-olds, headed by Yield, 2, T2:00.3, the fastest of his age and gait in 1973, Christopher T., 2, 2:01.4, Anvil, 2, 2:02, Armbro Ouzo, 2, 2:02.3, and the top-ranked colt in the USTA exper imental ratings, Nevele Diamond, 2, 2;04.3f. Fastest of the fillies is tlie ace Canadian stakes-winner .Sing Away Herbert, 2, 2:05.1, who like Nevele Diamond is from the first crop by Nevele Pride. Star's Pride, the Futurity winner in 1950, has 12 sons eligible;; Speedy Scot, 1963 winner, has 11; Nevele Pride (1968) has 9, as has Ayres (1964). Speedster lias eight still eligible, and Hickory Pride seven. Bill Gallon, who won the Futmity 33 years ago, has one .son eligible, sired when he was 32. Green colts and fillies with no record as 2-year-olds out- miinber those who were winuers last year. Only 3'l Jif the SO cligiblos were in the winning column in 1973. The events are .set for Medina on April 6 and May 25, Wooster on April 27 and June 15, and Wellington Name- Address. on May 11 and July 4. Rain dates for all matinees are the following Saturdays. Ribbons will be presented at the matinee while awards are part of the an nual Banquet features. Awards go to the highest scoring horses in each division that has at least three series .starts.
